ComparisonWithNaN.description:
Description

Reports comparisons with double and floatNaN(Not-a-Number) values.
These arespecifiedto have unintuitive behavior: NaN is considered unequal to itself.
This means a check likesomeDouble == Double.NaNwill always return
false, even ifsomeDoubleis really the NaN value. To test whether a
value is the NaN value, one should instead useDouble.isNaN(someDouble)(orFloat.isNaN). The!=operator should be treated similarly.
Finally, comparisons likesomeDouble <= Double.NaNare nonsensical
and will always evaluate to false.

This rule has been renamed from "BadComparison" in PMD 6.36.0.

Example(s):

Use this rule by referencing it:
ComparisonWithNaN.option: This rule has no specific options.
